awd_titl_txt: UNS:Multiresonator Photonic Crystal Enhanced Fluorescence and SERS
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Cunningham, Brian
1512043

The goal of this proposal is to develop a novel approach for coupling multiple optical cavities together to enhance the excitation of fluorescent emitters used for biological and chemical detection.  Wavelength-tuned external cavity lasers, photonic crystal resonator surfaces, and gold nanorods are combined to demonstrate large enhanced fluorescence detection of proteins.

Surface-based fluorescence assays and surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) are widely used in life science research, molecular diagnostics, and microscopy. There is strong motivation to improve their detection sensitivity while at the same time reducing the cost/complexity of detection instrumentation. This project would develop and characterize a fundamentally new approach towards excitation of surface-adsorbed photon emitters and scatterers that can be applied towards surface-based fluorescent and SERS assays for biomolecular analytes used in life science research, genomics, proteomics, diagnostics, and environmental monitoring.  The approach incorporates inexpensively manufacturable nanostructured surfaces and an nexpensive, compact detection instrument that will facilitate broad adoption. The project involves graduate research, undergraduate internships, integration of laboratory demonstrations into undergraduate courses, and activities that involve hands-on demonstrations to middle school children.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Our project established the theoretical framework and experimental demonstration of methods for efficiently funneling the energy associated with light from the macroscale to the nanometer scale.  Using nanostructures called "photonic crystals" that are inexpensively fabricated over large surface areas on glass, plastic, or silicon, we can capture light from lasers or LEDs and chennel it into specially engineered metallic nanopartilces that are applied to the photonic crystal surface.  Through careful selection of the properties of the photonic crystal and the metal nanoparticles, we demonstrated a novel phenomenon called "resonant hybrid coupling" in which light intensity on the nanoparticle surfaces can be several orders of magnitude greater than the intensity of the original light source.  Further, we developed methods for attaching a variety of molecules onto the gold nanoparticles, which are subsequently exposed to the enhanced electromagnetic fields.

The applications of resonant hybrid coupling are very broad and far-reaching.  In the field of ultrasensitive chemical detection, we demonstrated that we could boost the optical spectrum of scattered light from  a single nanoparticle to be clearly visible, in order to detect and identify only a handful of molecules using an inexpensive detection instrument.  In the field of biosensing, we demonstrated the ability to attach fluorescent dye molecules to the nanoparticles, resulting in a new technology called "plasmonic fluors" that we used to demonstrate ultrasensitive detection of protein molecules used as biomarkers for disease diagnostics.  We also demonstrated that the enhanced electric fields excite electron oscillation in the metal nanoparticles to generate high energy "hot" electrons that can be used to calalyze a variety of chemical reactions using light. 

The principles of resonant hybrid coupling, developed for the first time in this grant using photonic crystal optical resonators and gold nanoparticles, can be applied broadly to any type of optical resonator in communication with nanoantennas and nanoparticles with matching resonant properties.  We envision that the approach can be applied in the context of hybrid structures that are fabricated in a self-assembled "bottoms-up" engineered fasion (as demonstrated in our work), as well as with engineered "top-down" approaches in which nanoantenna structures are fabricated in ordered arrays with carefully controlled nanoparticle density.  In addition to photonic crystal surfaces, our approach may be adapted to ring resonators, beam cavity resonators, dielectric mirror resonators, and many other systems.


Last Modified: 07/07/2019
Modified by: Brian Cunningham

  • When optical modes of the nanoantenna and the resonant microcavity overlap in both spatial and spectral domains to form a hybrid resonance, their synergistic interaction can lead to a local near-field enhancement that is orders-of-magnitude stronger in comparson to either structure alone.i
    Cunningham Group, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
    Brian Cunningham
    Resonant hyrid coupling from a photonic crystal to a gold nano antenna
  • Electromagnetic simulation demonstrating enhanced absorption of light when a gold nanostar is coupled to a photonic crystal surface. Approximately four orders of magnitude intensity is obtained on the surface of the AuNS, accompanied by enhanced power dissipation and heating.
    Cunningham Group, University of Illinois at Urbana-Cn
    Copyrighted
    Brian Cunningham
    Resonant coupling to a gold nanostar (AuNS)
  • SEM image of the microbead shows uniform binding of plasmonic-fluor-Cy3 with no sign of aggregation. The binding of plasmonic-fluor-Cy3 did not alter the size and shape of the bead or the optical barcode signal.
    Singamaneni Group, Washington University
    Copyrighted
    Brian Cunningham
    Uniform distribution of plasmonic-fluor-Cy3 on microbeads in a bead-based immunoassay
  • Plasmonic nanostructures conjugated with organic fluorophores have been employed as ultrabright nanolabels for enhancing the sensitivity of bead-based immunoassays by nearly 100-fold. The approach developed here is broadly applicable in a wide variety of bioanalytical technologies rel
    Singamaneni Group, Washington University
    Copyrighted
    Brian Cunningham
    Plasmonically-enhanced fluorescent nanolabels as ?add-on? signal enhancers
por.por_txt_cntn:
Our project established the theoretical framework and experimental demonstration of methods for efficiently funneling the energy associated with light from the macroscale to the nanometer scale.  Using nanostructures called "photonic crystals" that are inexpensively fabricated over large surface areas on glass, plastic, or silicon, we can capture light from lasers or LEDs and chennel it into specially engineered metallic nanopartilces that are applied to the photonic crystal surface.  Through careful selection of the properties of the photonic crystal and the metal nanoparticles, we demonstrated a novel phenomenon called "resonant hybrid coupling" in which light intensity on the nanoparticle surfaces can be several orders of magnitude greater than the intensity of the original light source.  Further, we developed methods for attaching a variety of molecules onto the gold nanoparticles, which are subsequently exposed to the enhanced electromagnetic fields.

The applications of resonant hybrid coupling are very broad and far-reaching.  In the field of ultrasensitive chemical detection, we demonstrated that we could boost the optical spectrum of scattered light from  a single nanoparticle to be clearly visible, in order to detect and identify only a handful of molecules using an inexpensive detection instrument.  In the field of biosensing, we demonstrated the ability to attach fluorescent dye molecules to the nanoparticles, resulting in a new technology called "plasmonic fluors" that we used to demonstrate ultrasensitive detection of protein molecules used as biomarkers for disease diagnostics.  We also demonstrated that the enhanced electric fields excite electron oscillation in the metal nanoparticles to generate high energy "hot" electrons that can be used to calalyze a variety of chemical reactions using light. 

The principles of resonant hybrid coupling, developed for the first time in this grant using photonic crystal optical resonators and gold nanoparticles, can be applied broadly to any type of optical resonator in communication with nanoantennas and nanoparticles with matching resonant properties.  We envision that the approach can be applied in the context of hybrid structures that are fabricated in a self-assembled "bottoms-up" engineered fasion (as demonstrated in our work), as well as with engineered "top-down" approaches in which nanoantenna structures are fabricated in ordered arrays with carefully controlled nanoparticle density.  In addition to photonic crystal surfaces, our approach may be adapted to ring resonators, beam cavity resonators, dielectric mirror resonators, and many other systems.
